UAE Abolishes ESR Reporting and Relaxes Corporate Tax Compliance Requirements 


In order to enhance companies’ compliance with the UAE corporate tax system, the UAE Ministry of Finance amended Cabinet decision No. 57/2020 on the 14th of October 2024 cancelling economic substance reporting requirements for companies with a financial year ending after 31 December 2022. Cabinet Resolution 57 of 2020 (the Regulations) imposes Economic Substance requirements on certain persons (licensees) carrying on relevant activities in the UAE.

The Regulations in summary require that the licensee files an annual notification and ESR report illustrating its compliance with the economic substance test.



Grace Period for Tax Records Updates and Penalty Waivers 


The Federal Tax Authority (FTA) has unveiled a new initiative on 12 November 2024 aimed at supporting UAE companies and relaxing their corporate tax compliance. 

Key features of this initiative include, allowing companies between 1 January 2024 to 31 March 2025 to update their records without facing administrative penalties.



UAE To Implement E-invoicing System 


The UAE has been moving at a fast pace towards a digital, paperless economy, including with the announcement on the 10th of November 2024 of its latest initiative towards achieving this objective: the launch of a comprehensive e-invoicing system expected in 2026.

Saudi Arabia Unveils New Retirement System 


A new retirement system with early retirement pre-conditions was announced by the Saudi General Organisation for Social Insurance on the 14th of October 2024. Key features of this new system include:

- Retirement age for subscribers to the new system is 65 years
- Minimum age for early retirement for subscribers to the new system is 55 years
- Minimum number of years in service to avail the retirement pension is 30 years
- Minimum retirement pension is 4,000 Saudi Riyals for those whose subscription period is 40 years.



Saudi Arabia Prohibits Use of Countries’ Logos and Symbols in Commerce 


A ministerial decision was issued by the Saudi Ministry of Commerce on the 16th of November 2024 providing legal protection to countries’ symbols and logos by banning their use in commerce throughout the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. 

In line with this decision, legal proceedings will be initiated against the violators in accordance with the regulations and penalties regulating municipal violations. The legal proceedings and penalties related thereto will come into force 90 days after the publication of this ministerial decision in the official gazette, granting commercial establishments and institutions a reasonable time to comply with the requirements of the decision before implementing it.



Saudi Arabia Design Law Treaty Adopted by WIPO 


Member States of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) adopted during a diplomatic conference which concluded in Riyadh on the 22nd of November 2024 the “Riyadh Design Law Treaty”.

Saudi Arabia Design Law Treaty Adopted by WIPO 


Member States of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) adopted during a diplomatic conference which concluded in Riyadh on the 22nd of November 2024 the “Riyadh Design Law Treaty”. 

This move represents a significant milestone in KSA’s efforts to protect Intellectual Property Rights and as a result to encourage investments in the Kingdom.



Saudi Arabia: VAT Refund for Tourists 


Good news for tourists visiting Saudi Arabia in 2025 as the Kingdom will introduce a VAT refund system as part of its strategy to position itself as a destination of choice for tourists. 

This initiative, which is a part of Saudi Arabia’s National Tourism Strategy, will be implemented by the Zakat, Tax, and Customs Authority with the aim of streamlining tax compliance and enhancing tourists’ experience


Saudi Arabia Labour Law Amendments (Continued)


Following up on this story featured in our third edition of the GCC Legal Updates newsletter where Resolution No. 51848/1442 brought sweeping reforms to the Saudi Labor Law of 2005, an announcement was made by The Ministry of Human Resources and Social Development (“MHRSD”) announcing that these new amendments will come into effect on 18 February 2025. 

Implementing Regulations will contain further details about these amendments, however as we get closer to the effective date referred to above, new updates are emerging pertaining to key features of these new amendments affecting different categories.

Saudi Arabia Enhances Sukuk and Debt Instruments Market 


KSA’s Capital Market Authority (CMA) recently introduced a series of key amendments regulating the areas of Sukuk and bond issuances in the Kingdom. 

These amendments represent an important milestone contributing to the growth of the national economy and will enable sukuks and debt market to become one of the primary tools for financing businesses and the economy.



Saudi Arabia Amends Laws on Commercial Registrations and Trade Names 


In line with Saudi Arabia’s Vision 20230, The Council of Ministers adopted in September 2024 the new Commercial Registration Law and Tradename Law which will take effect in April 2025. 

These new Laws aim to cement a business-friendly environment in Saudi Arabia by easing company registration procedures, enhancing digital and technology tools in addition to safeguarding intellectual property protection for tradenames.

Trademarks Search in Qatar Now Available Through WIPO 


The last quarter of 2024 witnessed an advanced and progressive move in relation to Qatar’s Intellectual Property Rights as the Qatari Ministry of Commerce and Industry launched its trademark database on the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO)’s Global Brand Database. 

This move allows any third parties interested in registering their trademarks in Qatar to search the database through the Global Brand Database (wipo.int) website before initiating the registration procedures.

The search through wipo.int will provide the interested parties with the requisite information as to whether or not a particular brand/concept is registered as a trademark in the Qatari market which will give them a clear indication on the chances of success of their trademark applications in Qatar and if their brand/concept ifs free and available for use in the Qatari market.


Electronic Payment Enforcement


The Ministry of Commerce and Industry in Qatar has issued a decision in the final quarter of the year requiring commercial establishments operating in the country to provide electronic payment services to their customers. 

In this regard, the Ministry is launching an organised campaign across the country to monitor and enforce electronic payment methods as a service offered by stores to their customers.

New Regulations for the Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes 


The Kuwaiti Finance Ministry issued on 28 September 2024 executive regulations for the decree-law on the exchange of information for tax purposes, in accordance with Kuwait Decree No. 75/2024 and Kuwait Decree-Law No. 6/2024. 

Key features of these new regulations include:

- Outlining the necessary procedures and requirements for adopting and executing agreements related to the exchange of tax information between Kuwait and other countries
- Determining reporting requirements, requesting additional information from financial institutions, and ensuring compliance with the agreed standards for exchanging tax-related data.
- Improving transparency and facilitating the exchange of relevant financial information for tax purposes between Kuwait and its partner nations.
